prior_works.title: Discrete analogues of self-decomposability and stability
prior_works.authors: W. F. Steutel, K. van Harn
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced the binomial thinning operator that underpins the branching mechanism in PB-SCM, providing the exact structural primitive the paper exploits for modeling causal propagation in count data.

prior_works.title: First-order integer-valued autoregressive (INAR(1)) process
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the canonical combination of binomial thinning (branching) with independent Poisson innovations (additive noise), the same compositional ingredients assumed in the Poisson Branching Structural Causal Model.

prior_works.title: Branching Processes
prior_works.authors: K. B. Athreya, P. E. Ney
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the probability generating function calculus for branching systems that the paper leverages to derive identifiability conditions beyond cumulant-based criteria.

prior_works.title: Learning Poisson DAG models
prior_works.role: Causal discovery for count data (Poisson SEM)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Developed identifiability and learning principles for Poisson structural equation models, forming the count-data causal discovery baseline that the PB-SCM setting extends by explicitly modeling branching via thinning.

prior_works.title: Hawkes processes in finance: a review
prior_works.authors: E. Bacry, I. Mastromatteo, J.-F. Muzy
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Surveyed branching representations and cumulant/second-order methods for causal network inference in self-exciting processes, motivating the cumulant-based approach that the paper shows can miss identifiable directions in discrete branching SCMs.

prior_works.title: Causal Inference using Additive Noise Models
prior_works.authors: J. Peters, D. Janzing, B. Schölkopf
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the modern template of using structural noise-model asymmetries for causal identifiability, a principle the paper adapts to the count/branching regime with Poisson noise and thinning.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s key contribution—establishing identifiability of Poisson Branching Structural Causal Models (PB-SCM) via probability generating functions (PGFs) and closing gaps left by cumulant-based methods—rests on three converging lines of prior work. First, the structural primitives of PB-SCM trace directly to the binomial thinning operator of Steutel and van Harn and its concrete use with Poisson innovations in INAR models by Al-Osh and Alzaid. These works formalized the branching-plus-Poisson-noise composition that PB-SCM adopts as its causal data-generating mechanism. Second, Athreya and Ney’s classic PGF calculus for branching processes provides the analytic toolkit the authors leverage to characterize and prove identifiability: PGFs encode the entire count distribution and interact cleanly with thinning and summation, enabling directionality to be teased apart where moment/cumulant summaries can be insufficient. Third, Poisson SEM/DAG literature (Park and Raskutti) established identifiability and scalable learning for count-data causal models but without explicit branching operators; PB-SCM extends this paradigm by aligning the structural equations with known branching dynamics. In parallel, cumulant-based identification used in branching/self-exciting processes (as surveyed by Bacry et al.) inspired earlier provably sound methods, yet the present work shows such cumulant criteria can miss identifiable directions in discrete branching SCMs. Finally, the broader ANM identifiability framework (Peters et al.) informs the paper’s strategy of exploiting model-specific asymmetries—here, through PGFs tailored to thinning-plus-Poisson—to obtain stronger identifiability guarantees.
